1 The Fund's blended benchmark comprises 80% S&P Global 1200 Healthcare Index, 15% S&P 500 Healthcare Corporate Bond Index, 5% S&P Composite 1500 Healthcare REITS Index.

The S&P Global 1200 Healthcare Index includes securities of those companies listed on the S&P Global 1200 Index classified according to the Industry Classification Benchmark as healthcare. The S&P Global 1200 Index is an unmanaged index considered representative of the global equity market, which captures roughly 70% of global market capitalization.

The S&P 500 Healthcare Corporate Bond Index includes securities of those companies listed on the S&P 500 Bond Index classified according to the Industry Classification Benchmark as healthcare. The S&P 500 Bond Index is an unmanaged index that comprises the corporate debt of those companies listed on the S&P 500 Index, which is considered representative of the U.S. stock market.

The S&P Composite 1500 Healthcare REITS Index includes securities of those companies listed on the S&P Composite 1500 Index classified according to the Industry Classification Benchmark as healthcare REITs. The S&P Composite 1500 Index is a broad market portfolio representing the large-, mid- and small-cap segments of the U.S. equity market.

Indexes are unmanaged and have been provided for comparison purposes only. No fees or expenses are reflected. You cannot invest directly in an index.

For current holdings information, please visit abrdn World Healthcare Fund (THW) - Portfolio Holdings

Performance was held back by three detractors. Among these, uniQure (QURE) underperformed after regulatory expectations shifted, with U.S. Food and Drug Administration feedback challenging its proposed filing strategy for Huntington's disease, reducing visibility on the approval pathway. Mereo BioPharma Group (MREO) also detracted after its Phase III osteogenesis imperfecta trial failed to meet its primary endpoint, representing a material setback for the investment case. Precision BioSciences (DTIL) further detracted as a capital raise heightened dilution concerns, weighing on sentiment towards early-stage gene-editing companies.

Positive contributions were led by Abivax (ABVX), the Fund's strongest performer, as confidence built around obefazimod after robust Phase III induction data in ulcerative colitis. A broader re-rating of SMID-cap biotechnology also supported performance. AstraZeneca (AZN) contributed strongly as investors favored large-cap pharmaceutical companies with durable earnings and consistent execution, while Eli Lilly (LLY) continued to perform well on sustained enthusiasm for its incretin franchise, supported by expanding indications and improving manufacturing visibility.

Market review

Global healthcare performance in 2025 was shaped more by shifting investor tolerance for uncertainty than by any lack of innovation. The sector lagged broader equity markets for much of the year as investors focused on perceived "safe" growth themes, most notably artificial intelligence, while healthcare faced regulatory, policy, pricing, and trade-related uncertainty.

This underperformance reflected sentiment and valuation rather than fundamentals. Healthcare entered 2025 trading at one of the widest valuation discounts to global equities in decades, a gap that widened further after new U.S. tariffs announced in April triggered a sharp sell-off, particularly in small- and mid-cap (SMID-cap) biotechnology. As tariff concerns eased, valuations rebounded, driven by company-specific execution, improving balance sheets and visible clinical or regulatory catalysts.

The fourth quarter marked a turning point as policy overhangs eased and interest rates declined. U.S. Federal Reserve rate cuts supported research and development-intensive businesses, while accelerating mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity reinforced the strategic value of differentiated assets. Despite volatility linked to a U.S. government shutdown, healthcare's defensive characteristics proved resilient, with more constructive conditions also emerging outside the U.S.

Activity

During the quarter, activity focused on reallocating capital towards higher-upside opportunities, particularly within SMID-cap healthcare and globally differentiated assets that are less widely followed by U.S.-centric investors, while trimming exposure to heavily owned large-cap companies.

New positions spanned therapeutics, diagnostics, and enabling technologies, including Ascendis (ASND), CareDx (CDNA), Disc Medicine (IRON), Praxis (PRAX), Structure Therapeutics (GPCR), Oxford Nanopore (ONTTF), GPCR-focused therapeutics, Quoin Pharma (QNRX), and Ironwood (IRWD)-related innovation exposure. Additional exposure was added through Perceptive Capital Solutions aligned with Freenome, alongside the initiation of Veradermics as a venture investment to access early-stage innovation.

On the disposal side, positions were sold where conviction had diminished, including Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Pfizer (PFE), ResMed (RMD), Veradigm (MDRX), Exact Sciences (EXAS), Community Health Systems (CYH), BioNTech (BNTX), Prenetics (PRE), and Mereo BioPharma after its Phase III setback in osteogenesis imperfecta. Bond exposure was modestly reduced, with capital tilted towards equity opportunities while maintaining a meaningful fixed-income allocation.

Outlook & strategy

Looking ahead to 2026, we believe the global healthcare sector is entering a more constructive phase. After several years of relative underperformance, valuations across many parts of healthcare—particularly outside the most heavily owned U.S. mega-cap companies—remain attractive compared with the broader equity market. While macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty is unlikely to disappear, we view the balance of risks and opportunities as improving, especially as interest rates have begun to ease and policy-related headwinds appear less acute than earlier in 2025.

Importantly, the long-term fundamentals underpinning healthcare remain firmly intact. Aging populations, rising prevalence of chronic disease, and continued innovation across oncology, rare disease, neurology, and enabling technologies continue to drive demand globally. At the same time, accelerating M&A activity highlights the strategic value of differentiated assets and reinforces our view that high-quality innovation is scarce and increasingly sought after by large pharmaceutical and life sciences companies.

Our strategy is designed to take advantage of this environment through a globally diversified, actively managed portfolio. We continue to emphasize SMID healthcare companies, where valuation dispersion is greatest and where company-specific execution can meaningfully drive returns. We are particularly focused on identifying non-U.S. opportunities that may be underappreciated by U.S.-centric investors, while maintaining exposure to select U.S. companies where we believe the risk-reward remains compelling.

We also complement public equity holdings with selective venture investments and maintain a diversified portfolio construction that includes fixed income, even after modest adjustments. This balanced approach allows us to participate in healthcare's innovation upside while managing volatility through different market environments. We remain optimistic about the opportunity set ahead and are committed to disciplined capital allocation as we seek to deliver long-term value for shareholders.

References

  1. 1. The Fund's blended benchmark comprises 80% S&P Global 1200 Healthcare Index, 15% S&P 500 Healthcare Corporate Bond Index, 5% S&P Composite 1500 Healthcare REITS Index.

Important Information

International investing entails special risk considerations, including currency fluctuations, lower liquidity, economic and political risks, and differences in accounting methods; these risks are generally heightened for emerging market investments.

data.title: American Century One Choice Target Date Portfolios Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
All nine One Choice Portfolios posted positive returns in the fourth quarter.

Market Environment

Global stocks advanced in the fourth quarter. Non-U.S. developed markets equities outperformed U.S. stocks. Large-cap equities outperformed small- and mid-cap stocks in the quarter, while value-oriented stocks outperformed growth.

The U.S. economy continued expanding, but growth slowed somewhat as the quarter progressed. The U.S. government shutdown that began in October and dragged into early November did not dramatically deter investors, even as it delayed or eliminated key government economic data. The Federal Reserve, reacting to weakness in the U.S. labor market, reduced its benchmark interest rate twice during the quarter.

Bonds had a positive quarter across the board. Nearly all sectors of the bond market advanced. Treasuries slightly outperformed investment-grade corporates. Corporate bond returns were limited by the same economic uncertainty that weighed on U.S. equities during the period. Investment-grade U.S. bonds outperformed non-U.S. bonds on a currency-neutral basis.

Key Contributors

International holdings led the way. Top absolute performers in the applicable portfolios were International Value, Non-U.S. Intrinsic Value, Emerging Markets and Focused Dynamic Growth.

Nearly all bond positions gained. Across fixed-income holdings, Emerging Markets Debt, High Income and Short Duration were top performers.

Key Detractors

Few absolute detractors for the quarter. In a strong environment for both equities and bonds, only Heritage, Small Cap Value, Inflation-Adjusted Bond and Global Real Estate generated negative returns during the quarter.

Outlook and Dynamic Risk Management Process

We continue to see innovation and opportunity in equity markets. The financial markets delivered positive returns in 2025 despite the backdrop of geopolitical and policy uncertainties. Similarly, U.S. economic growth remains resilient.

Economic and market risks remain, however. On the one hand, interest rate and tax cuts are likely to be supportive of growth and equities. On the other hand, the U.S. stock market remains very expensive and highly concentrated. We expect volatility to be a constant companion in the new year.

In the fixed-income markets, sector and security selection will be crucial. The current environment of elevated government spending, growing fiscal debt and inflecting interest rates favors an active and nimble approach to fixed-income portfolio management.

Diversification and risk management remain central to successful approaches. Geopolitical, economic and market uncertainties put a premium on prudent risk management going forward.

Dynamic risk positioning reflects balance of risks. At the end of September, we maintained our long-term, neutral glide path positioning, which is intended to address the various competing risks investors face across their lifetime. While stocks are at record highs, lower interest rates and better economic growth support higher valuations.

Commentary Glossary

Adjustable-Rate Mortgages (ARMs): Mortgages in which the interest rate is adjusted periodically according to a specific index.

Agency Securities (Agencies): Debt securities issued by U.S. government agencies.

Agency MBS: Mortgage-backed securities issued by U.S. government agencies.

Alternative Minimum Tax ('AMT'): A parallel tax system that was created to keep high income individuals from avoiding taxes through various deductions and exemptions.

Asset-Backed Securities ('ABS'): A form of securitized debt backed by loan assets such as auto loans, student loans, and credit card debt.

Basis Points ('BPS'): Used to express percentage values that are carried out to two decimal places. One basis point equals 0.01%.

Breakeven Rate: Yield difference between nominal Treasury notes and TIPS; indicates the market's expectations for inflation.

Carry-Oriented Currencies: Higher-yielding currencies of countries where interest rates are generally higher than those of countries with lower-yielding currencies. These higher-yielding currencies are targeted for "carry trades," where investors borrow money in a low-interest rate currency and invest in a higher yielding currency, potentially profiting from the difference in interest rates.

Collateralized Loan Obligations (CLOs): A form of securitized debt, typically backed by pools of corporate loans and their payments.

Collateralized Mortgage Obligations (CMOs): A form of structured, securitized debt derived from mortgage-backed securities, typically backed by pools of residential mortgages and their payments.

Commercial Mortgage-Backed Securities ('CMBS'): Securities representing ownership in pools of commercial real estate loans used to finance the construction and improvement of income-producing properties such as hotels, shopping centers, and office buildings.

Commercial Paper: Short-term debt issued by corporations to raise cash and to cover current expenses in anticipation of future revenues.

Commodity: Basic raw materials such as precious metals and natural resources.

Consumer Price Index ('CPI'): Published by the U.S. government, CPI is the most commonly used statistic to measure inflation in the U.S. economy. Core CPI excludes food and energy prices, which tend to be volatile.

Contribution to Duration ('CTD'): A measure of bond portfolio risk that reflects a bond sector's contribution to the overall duration of the portfolio.

Corporate Debt: Debt instruments issued by private corporations.

Covered Bonds: Debt securities backed by cash flows from pools of mortgages or public sector loans. The asset pools help secure or "cover" these bonds if the originating financial institution becomes insolvent.

Coupon Interest Rate: The interest rate that is assigned to an interest-paying fixed income security when it is issued.

Credit Analysis: An analysis of the financial strength of the issuer of a security, and the ability of that issuer to provide timely payment of interest and principal.

Credit Default Swap: Credit derivative contracts between two counterparties that can be used to hedge credit risk or speculate on the changes in the credit quality of a corporation or government entity.

Credit Quality: Measures (usually in terms of high or low) the ability of issuers of debt securities to make timely interest and principal payments.

Credit Risk: The risk that the inability of the issuers of debt securities to make payments will cause these securities to decline in value.

Currency Overlay: A financial trading strategy used to separate the management of currency risk from other portfolio strategies. A currency overlay manager can seek to hedge the risk from adverse movements in exchange rates, and/or attempt to profit from tactical currency views.

Debt Service: The amount of money required within a given period to keep current on required/scheduled repayments of outstanding debt, including interest and principal.

Deflation: A decline in prices for goods, assets and services.

Derivatives: Securities whose performance and/or structure is derived from the performance and/or structure of other assets, interest rates or indexes.

Duration: A measure of the price sensitivity of a fixed income investment to changes in interest rates. The longer the duration, expressed in years, the more a fixed income investment's price will change when interest rates change.

Emerging Markets ('EM') Debt: Debt issued by countries whose economies are considered to be developing or emerging from underdevelopment.

Excess Return: The return of an investment portfolio minus the return of what is considered to be a relatively risk-free asset, such as a U.S. Treasury bill.

Exchange-Traded Fund ('ETF'): Represents a group of securities but is traded on an exchange like an individual stock.

Federal Funds Rate: An overnight interest rate banks charge each other for loans.

Federal Open Market Committee ('FOMC'): The committee that sets interest rate and credit policies for the Federal Reserve System, the U.S. central bank.

Federal Reserve (Fed): The U.S. central bank, responsible for monetary policies affecting the U.S. financial system and the economy.

Fundamental Factors: Economic or financial data used in determining asset value.

Futures Contracts (Futures): Agreements to buy or sell a specific amount of a commodity or financial instrument at a particular price on a stipulated future date.

General Obligation ('GO') Bonds: Municipal bonds that are secured by the full faith and credit of the issuer, including its taxing power.

Gross Domestic Product ('GDP'): A measure of the total economic output in goods and services for an economy.

Government-Sponsored Enterprises (GSEs): Privately owned corporations created by Congress to provide funding and help to reduce the cost of capital for certain borrowing sectors of the economy such as homeowners, students and farmers.

Headline Risk: Refers to the risk that a negative news media headline about one security issuer, incident or sector could affect the demand for and pricing of a much wider swath of securities.

Hedge: An investment designed to reduce the risk of an adverse price move in another investment. Often a hedge consists of taking an offsetting position in a related investment, such as a futures contract.

High-Yield ('HY') Debt: Fixed income securities with lower credit quality and lower credit ratings. High-yield securities are rated below BBB-.

Hybrid Adjustable-Rate Mortgages (ARMs): Combine the characteristics of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages, with rates remaining fixed for a set period of time and then adjusting periodically according to a specific index.

Inflation: An economic condition of rising prices for goods, services and assets, or equivalently, a declining value of money. Core inflation excludes food and energy prices, which tend to be volatile. It is the opposite of Deflation.

Inflation-Indexed Securities: Debt securities that offer returns adjusted for inflation. Typically, the principal of inflation-indexed securities is indexed to a widely used inflation measure and adjusted accordingly. Interest payments can be adjusted as well.

Interest Rate Risk: The risk that a fixed income investment's value will change due to changes in interest rates.

Investment-Grade ('IG') Debt: Fixed income securities with relatively high credit quality and credit ratings in the upper ranges of those provided by credit rating services. Using Standard & Poor's ratings as the benchmark, investment-grade securities are those rated BBB- or higher.

Leverage: The use of financial instruments and/or borrowed capital to increase potential returns or to increase purchasing power.

Long Position: Typical ownership of an asset or investment that gives the owner the right to transfer ownership, the right to any income generated by the asset, and the right to any profits or losses due to value changes.

Long/Short Position: A "market neutral" investing strategy that involves taking long positions in assets that are expected to increase in value and short positions in assets that are expected to decrease in value.

Master Limited Partnerships (MLPs): Publicly traded, generally higher-yielding securities of enterprises that engage in certain businesses, usually pertaining to the use of natural resources.

Mortgage-Backed Securities ('MBS'): A form of securitized debt that represents ownership in pools of mortgage loans and their payments.

MSCI ACWI (All Country World Index): A free float-adjusted market capitalization-weighted index that is designed to measure the equity market performance of developed and emerging markets.

Municipal Securities: Debt securities typically issued by or on behalf of U.S. state and local governments, their agencies or authorities to raise money for a variety of public purposes, including financing for state and local governments as well as financing for specific projects and public facilities.

Nominal Yield: The interest rate to par value that the bond issuer promises to pay bond purchasers.

Non-Agency Mortgage-Backed Securities ('MBS'): MBS are groups of home mortgages that are sold by the issuing banks and then packaged together into "pools" and sold as a single security. Non-agency MBS are issued by private entities, such as financial institutions.

Personal Consumption Expenditures ('PCE'): This price deflator which comes from the Bureau of Economic Analysis' quarterly report on U.S. gross domestic product is based on a survey of businesses and is intended to capture the price changes in all final goods, no matter the purchaser. Because of its broader scope and certain differences in the methodology used to calculate the PCE price index, the Federal Reserve holds the PCE deflator as its preferred, consistent measure of inflation over time.

Quantitative Easing ('QE'): A form of monetary policy used by central banks to stimulate economic growth by purchasing domestic government securities to increase the domestic money supply, lower interest rates and encourage investors to make investments in riskier assets such as stocks and high-yield securities.

Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs): Securities that trade like stocks and invest in real estate through properties or mortgages.

Real Yield: A yield that has been adjusted to remove the effects of inflation.

Revenue Bonds: Municipal bonds that are secured by the net revenues from the project or facility being financed.

S&P 500 Index: The S&P 500® Index is composed of 500 selected common stocks most of which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It is not an investment product available for purchase.

Secondary Market: A market where investors make purchases from other investors, rather than from the initial issuers.

Securitized Debt: Debt resulting from aggregating debt instruments into a pool of similar debts, then issuing new securities backed by the pool. ABS, MBS, and CMOs are common forms of securitized debt.

Short Position: Refers to the sale of an asset borrowed, not owned, by the seller in anticipation of a price decline. If the seller can buy the asset later (to return what was borrowed) at a lower price, a profit results. If the price rises, the borrower/seller suffers a loss.

Sovereign Debt: A country's government-issued debt, priced in its native currency, which can be sold to investors in other countries.

Spreads, Maturity Spreads, Credit Spreads: Measured differences between two interest rates or yields that are being compared with each other. Spreads typically are measured between fixed income securities of the same credit quality, but different maturities (maturity spreads), or of the same maturity, but different credit quality (credit spreads).

Spread Sectors: Non-Treasury debt sectors with securities that usually trade at higher yields than comparable-maturity U.S. Treasury securities. These sectors typically trade at higher yields than Treasuries because they usually have relatively higher credit risk and/or more risk of prepayment.

Spread Widening, Tightening: Changes in spreads that reflect changes in relative value, with spread widening usually indicating relative price depreciation and spread tightening indicating relative price appreciation.

Swaps: Two-party contracts entered into primarily by institutional investors for periods ranging from a few weeks to more than one year. In a standard "swap" transaction, two parties agree to exchange the returns (or differentials in rates of return) earned or realized on particular predetermined investments or instruments.

Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities ('TIPS'): Inflation-linked debt securities issued by the U.S. Treasury.

Technical Factors: Market price behavior, trends, volume, and momentum data used in determining asset value.

U.S. Treasury securities: Debt securities issued by the U.S. Treasury and backed by the direct "full faith and credit" pledge of the U.S. government. Treasury securities include bills (maturing in one year or less), notes (maturing in two to 10 years) and bonds (maturing in more than 10 years). They are generally considered among the highest quality and most liquid securities in the world.

Variable-Rate Demand Notes (VRDNs): Short-term debt securities that track market interest rates using periodic (daily, weekly, monthly, or quarterly) interest rate adjustments.

Weighted Average Life to Maturity: The average time in years to receive the principal repayments.

Yield: A rate of return for bonds and other fixed-income securities. There are several types of yields and yield calculations.

Yield Curve: A line graph showing the yields of fixed income securities from a single sector from a range of different maturities at a single point in time.

Yield to Maturity: A common performance calculation for fixed income securities, which takes into account total annual interest payments, the purchase price, the redemption value, and the amount of time remaining until maturity.

Real Yield to Maturity: Yield to maturity minus any "inflation premium" that had been added/priced in.

Zero-Coupon Securities: Debt securities that are sold at a deep discount then redeemed for their full face value at maturity.

Glossary Sources: American Century Investments, Bloomberg Indices.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

One IPO and six SPACs came to market this past week, and one major issuer joined the pipeline as February comes to a close.

Generate Biomedicines (GENB) priced its IPO at the midpoint to raise $400 million at a $2.2 billion market cap. The Flagship Pioneering-incubated biotech is using its AI platform, which combines programmable capabilities with biohardware and data, to develop drugs with both precision and scale. Its most advanced candidate is in Phase 3 trials for severe asthma. Generate finished down 21%.

The week’s six blank check IPOs were led by MOZAYYX Acquisition (MZYX.U), which raised $261 million to target fintech, energy, cybersecurity, and other high-growth areas.

data.title: SPYI: I Spy An Expensive Way To Underperform -- Strong Sell
data.description:
Introduction

The NEOS S&P 500 High Income ETF (SPYI) is a fund that aims to provide consistent income for investors, based on monthly payouts, with the potential for slight upside gain captured in rising markets. This fund uses a call option driven strategy, which includes both sold and purchased SPX index options. Please see the below image from the website for some details of the fund.

As its underlying index is the S&P 500, their top holdings are the largest names in the S&P.

We are naturally bullish on the long-term direction of the broader US markets, represented by the S&P 500, but as a result, believe that investors would be better suited simply buying a standard ETF that tracks the index, at a much lower expense ratio, than this fund, which provides subpar returns on a total value basis.

In the below section, we will cover some news and macro trends that may impact the general market, which affects this fund.

Relevant News that Impacts the Broader Market, and Therefore, SPYI

The AI investment cycle remains in full swing

As we have seen from numerous big tech earnings this quarter, the AI investment cycle remains ongoing. For chip suppliers, such as NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) and Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) earnings have been record high for both firms. On the buyer side, hyperscalers have all been raising their CapEx expenses, most of which is headed towards investments in AI related activities. See the below chart from Bloomberg that highlights this investment wave.

This massive increase in AI related CapEx has many downstream impacts, spanning chip suppliers, manufacturers of chips, data center real estate investors, cooling and infrastructure, power suppliers, and many more. We believe that ultimately, this massive push to build out AI infrastructure will remain the leading investment angle for the foreseeable future, and this should help to provide a floor for many of the large technology companies that make up an overweight portion of S&P 500 earnings.

Global Conflicts Remain a Presence Across Multiple Markets

There are still numerous conflicts that pose a risk to overall market stability that we should keep in mind as investors in 2026. Right now, the most imminent threat remains the possible conflict in Iran, as US warships and military might continue to grow in the region. This is certainly not an ideal situation, but from an investment perspective, wars and conflicts require funding and aerospace and defense companies also make up a portion of the S&P. A notable consideration is that across NATO allies, defense spending is increasing dramatically, and this should serve as another tailwind for investors to keep an eye on. View the following graph from the Atlantic Council that shows current NATO spending levels.

With the new goal of 5% of GDP for all members, you can clearly see that every single member of NATO has a ways to go before they reach this new bar. This push in increasing spending will serve as a strong tailwind for the sector and many firms in the S&P.

Lower Interest Rates Will Help to Boost Spending

As rates go lower, there will be more spending and investment as cheaper money rolls around. For the first time in years, mortgage rates have fallen below 6%, which of course is a sign that the Federal Funds rate is also on the way down. With rates at their lowest in 3 years, we believe that there may be increased spending that results from this, in addition to savings from AI. See the below graph that shows the rate over the past 3 years, from Trading Economics.

As this remains the case, we believe that there will be consistently more growth and investment across the board, and this should help serve as a boost for the market as well.

Performance is Subpar

Considering that SPYI’s goal is to “distribute high monthly income generated from investing in the constituents of the S&P 500 Index and implementing a data-driven call option strategy”, we will compare how it performs against the S&P 500. As a proxy to the S&P 500 we will use an S&P 500 ETF, VOO.

Above is a 3 year performance comparison of the 2. Note that we are looking at “total returns” here which also account for dividends.

We see that VOO is clearly beating SPYI, by 20% across the last 3 years. In the beginning of the period, we see that the 2 had very similar performance, but over time VOO pulled out ahead.

We see this as a bearish sign for SPYI. The fund is positioned to provide exposure to the S&P 500 while also primarily focused on generating income. Despite the net credit call strategy, its participation in the SP500's rallies is capped while exposure to the downside has no structural protection. As such, we see that investors would have been better off just buying and holding VOO. This is especially an issue when you compare VOO’s expense ratio of 0.03% to SPYI’s expense ratio of 0.68% (22.67x larger).

Risks

There are sectors at risk, such as commercial real estate, that could alarm investors broadly.

With $2 trillion of real estate debt coming due soon, lenders are starting to become nervous about borrowers repaying their loans. This could cause a panic in the markets if a large borrow declares bankruptcy, or if this leads to other signs of contagion. However, we believe that this risk is low as leading real estate firms such as Costar have outlined options for scaling this wall of debt, and since the issues stemming from the financial crisis, lenders are more well-built to remain solvent and less risky than before.

There is a Downturn in the Market

In our comparison chart in the previous section, we see that when the market is in a downturn, SPYI does perform better than VOO. Zooming into the downturn period in the chart we see:

SPYI outperformed VOO by about 2% in this period from Feb 14th 2025 to April 8th 2025. This is due to the funds covered call spread strategy where a cheaper option is purchased while a more expensive one is sold. This provides the fund with some instant profit and creates a better performance than the underlying equity during downturns. However the strategy also provides lower profits as the underlying equity increases in value.

Conclusion

The broader market and S&P 500 remain ideal long-term investments for an investor. There are significant tailwinds that should be pushing the markets towards new highs, including AI CapEx, defense spending, and lower rates boosting expenditures everywhere. We believe that these factors are bullish and should provide long-term investors solid growth in the years to come.

As such, SPYI is not a good option for investors at this point. The market has a lot of tailwinds pushing its value up in the short term and a covered call spread would decrease your participation in those gains. On a total return basis, SPYI has lagged behind VOO consistently as a result. The S&P 500 has historically increased over decades, and it's not a good idea to bet against the market. Hard pass — just buy VOO and save 22.67x on expense ratios.

H2 2025 Letter

Here is the link to River Oaks Capital's previous letters: Past Letters

River Oaks Capital is open for new investors, if you or anyone you know is interested in learning more about our fund, please visit our website or e-mail me at whuguley@rivoaks-capital.com

Thank you to all who have expressed your interest in River Oak Capital's letters. They tend to be long and in-depth, much like the research River Oaks does on a company before we buy ownership. To that end, I have started a table of contents, to make the letter more navigable.

  1. I. Investment Philosophy & Thoughts
  2. II. Companies added in the Past Year
  3. III. Updates from H2 2024 Letter
  4. IV. Mistakes

I. Investment Philosophy & Overview

"Someone's sitting in the shade today because someone planted a tree a long time ago."- Warren Buffett

Before diving in, I'd encourage you to revisit past letters – many ideas here build on earlier ones that would be too long to re-introduce.

Six years ago, I started River Oaks Capital with a simple premise: find the small, underfollowed public companies in overlooked corners of the markets where wonderful businesses hide in plain sight, unnoticed and undervalued.

I knew this meant putting in a tremendous amount of 'boots on the ground' work. However, what I didn't fully appreciate then was how much that work would evolve over time.

Six years into running River Oaks Capital, one lesson keeps intensifying – achieving above-average returns in these companies requires rolling up my sleeves more and more.

Before I dive in deeper here, let's quickly review the capital raising process every company goes through – discussed in detail in the H1 2024 letter .

At some point in nearly every company's growth journey, outside capital is needed.

For generations, the traditional U.S. path was an IPO on the NASDAQ or NYSE.

But then the story changed. Private equity and venture capital emerged onto the scene and let many companies stay private until they were worth billions.

The pros and cons of each capital raising route is a topic for another time.

What has become abundantly clear over the six years of running River Oaks Capital is that the U.S. small, underfollowed public companies are becoming increasingly more ignored and thus undervalued.

The reason driving the depressed valuations of nearly every one of these companies is long listed and very often times warranted – as shown in the River Oaks Capital one pager (attached here) – only ~50-75 of the roughly 3,000 publicly traded, small, underfollowed companies universe checks all the boxes of a wonderful business.

This raises the obvious question that is often ask to me: why would any small company stay public, paying $1–2m+ per year for the "privilege" of being 50% undervalued?

I used to give a long winded, ten-minute answer – often addressing how many of these companies went public well before the cost of being public drastically increased and alternative forms of capital raising weren't available.

However, I was recently having a conversation with an investor friend of mine, and he cut straight to the chase: "Who cares? If they hadn't gone public, we couldn't buy them this cheap."

When nearly every investor ignores this universe, even the wonderful businesses get thrown out with the bathwater. That neglect is our opportunity to buy wonderful businesses at an extremely discounted valuation.

This is where the evolution of 'rolling up my sleeves' began.

The first 1-2 years of running River Oaks Capital: Finding the Gems

Early on, rolling up my sleeves meant getting on planes, meeting management teams in person, visiting competitors, attending conferences – the boots-on-the-groundwork required to find the handful of genuinely undervalued small, wonderful underfollowed public companies.

I soon discovered I was conducting rigorous due diligence that few perform in this area of the market.

I applied the same due diligence I would conduct before acquiring a 50% stake in a local private business – why should a small publicly traded company warrant a different approach?

The next few years: Actively Taking Advantage of Their Undervaluation

A few years in, I realized finding an undervalued small, wonderful, underfollowed business public company wasn't enough.

No light switch was going to flip these companies to fair value on their own.

So, each time I visit the management teams of almost every company we own, I give a rather simple suggestion to buy back as many shares as possible – using free cash flow from the business, cash on the balance sheet, and proceeds from non-core asset sales. Rather than getting frustrated over the undervaluation, let's take advantage of it.

Ideally, we buy ownership in wonderful companies who are already doing this (a handful of the companies we own already were).

However, many of the companies we own that previously had not implemented a share buyback program started one after the suggestion from myself alongside other shareholders.

The case to be made to management teams is quite simple: if your stock trades at 50 cents on the dollar, buying back shares can turn $1 into $2. There is no other area of the market that offers this easy of a capital allocation decision.

This approach allows us to be adequately compensated – 8–15%+ returns per year –until the company becomes properly valued.

The past year: The Part I'd Never Deeply Thought About

I'd thought carefully about how we find these companies.

I'd thought carefully how they should allocate capital until the company becomes properly valued.

What I realized I hadn't deeply thought about was the "until the company becomes properly valued" part. How will that eventually happen? Does it even need to happen if you are returning capital to shareholders at above average returns?

This was crystallized when we started buying ownership in Ascent Industries in the second half of the year.

I flew out to Chicago to meet CEO Brian Kitchen who opened my eyes to something I'd been realizing for years without ever fully identifying it: the importance of investing alongside management teams that not only have an unwavering long-term value creation plan but also actively work to manifest fair – or ideally premium – returns for patient shareholders.

Looking back, every one of our successful investments has this quality.

In many ways, this isn't a departure from what I've always focused on: finding a wonderful business with an A+ management team that reinvests excess free cash flow into high-return areas while repurchasing shares opportunistically.

However, it goes further, integrating a clear long-term business plan with maximum shareholder value creation.

In small, underfollowed public markets – where price discovery keeps shrinking – a long-term shareholder value creation plan matters more than ever.

Over my career, I've found only four long term value creation strategies that reliably work – which I will outline below using a company we own as an example for each.

They aren't mutually exclusive; The best companies often execute multiple of these strategies across various stages of long-term value creation.

However, a key requirement is that the business sustains above-average shareholder returns throughout the process, as long-term plans often exceed expected timelines – you don't want time to be your enemy.

Strategy 1: Grow your way out of being small and underfollowed – BuildDirect (BILD.V)

The long-term objective of a company using this maximum shareholder value business plan is to go after an underfollowed, fragmented market and grow the business through both organic growth and acquisitions to no longer be a small, underfollowed public company.

With proper execution and prudent capital allocation, they can grow large enough that the benefits of being a public company noticeably outweigh the negatives.

Shawn Wilson – CEO of BuildDirect– and his team have laid out this exact plan that entails a 10+ year methodical execution to grow their business to 75+ professional flooring stores across the U.S. through organic growth and acquisitions.

If they achieve this while using prudent capital allocation – more on how they have done so far in the following section – Shawn and his team will grow their free cash flow to over $50m+ per year in 10 years with no plans to stop there.

Their ultimate goal is to become North America's largest professional flooring company – a path that would almost certainly manifest the highest possible value for patient, long-term shareholders.

Critically, they're funding this growth through free cash flow from the business and prudent debt – not having to issue additional equity along the way.

Relying on your share price to fund acquisitions or organic growth carries significant risk – persistent mispricing can result in substantial dilution to long-term shareholders

This strategy can also be implemented through a holding company that gathers together a select number of unrelated small, underfollowed companies to create a larger parent company – which is being executed at Boston Omaha now.

Here, management's capital allocation is imperative, as you will need to overcome the hurdle of parent holding company costs.

Strategy 2: Dominate a niche market and become an irresistible acquisition target – Ascent Industries (ACNT)

This long-term business plan maximizes shareholder value by dominating a niche within a broader market, positioning the company as an attractive acquisition target for major industry players.

As the major players – larger strategic acquirers or private equity firms – look to expand their footprint in the broader industry, they will eventually be attracted to the niche area you have cornered.

CEO Brian Kitchen and his Ascent team are building dominance in a niche area of specialty chemicals that major players have left untouched.

Brian and his team have executed this strategy before at a different company and remain laser focused on doing so again.

Each of Brian's presentations clearly illustrates free cash flow before and after public company costs, providing a transparent view of standalone value available to a strategic or financial acquirer, excluding synergies.

The logic writes itself: it's cheaper for a major player to acquire a dominant niche player like Ascent Industries than spend the time, money and resources to compete against them head-on.

To reiterate, the business must generate above-average investor returns in the interim, as an acquisition may take years or decades.

Strategy 3: Divest the entire business to unlock the trapped shareholder value – Medical Facilities (DR.TO)

Sometimes the long-term plan that maximizes shareholder value is to admit you are better off selling the company piece by piece and returning capital to shareholders via a mixture of share buybacks and dividends.

Counterintuitively, long-term shareholders benefit most when the share price remains undervalued during the divestiture process, enabling management to maximize accretive share buybacks prior to the final cash distribution.

Around three years ago, activist investors stepped in at Medical Facilities, as the prior management's acquisition strategy wasn't working. Their stock price reflected as much.

Jason Redman was appointed CEO with a mandate to divest non-core assets and then the four core surgical hospitals – two of which are best-in-class facilities whose value was buried within a broader hospital conglomerate.

Jason and his team have now divested of all their non-core assets and sold two of their four surgical hospitals – with the sale of the final two most likely to happen in the near term.

They have methodically returned the cash generated from each sale back to shareholders by buying back undervalued shares and paying dividends when appropriate.

They have put on a master class on how to execute the strategy of divesting your entire business to unlock maximum value for long-term shareholders.

Strategy 4: Cut costs to a bare minimum and run like a private company – Truxton Trust (TRUX)

The fourth long-term value maximizing strategy is perfectly outlined by Truxton Trust.

CEO Tom Stumb and his team have kept public company costs to well below $500k per year – they have been extremely cost discipline since they went public more than 20 years ago.

They are listed on the lowest cost tier of the OTC Markets and don't allocate their time towards quarterly calls, investor conferences, or roadshows. Instead focusing all their attention on operating and growing their wonderful business.

Tom and his team have operated with the efficiency of a private company due to their large insider ownership at Truxton and the trust gained from their tightly held long-term shareholder base over the past two decades.

Additionally, how their shares are valued has no effect on their long-term business plans because they generate such an excess amount of free cash flow per year, they never plan on having to use their share price to raise money.

Furthermore, long-term investors don't care where the stock price is as Tom and his team have been growing free cash flow at 15%+ per year – positioning us to make above average returns just from the yearly cash distributions from the company.

The final result is a perfect balance: they operate with the efficiency of a private company while retaining the genuine benefits of being public – credibility with borrowers and depositors, share liquidity for employees and clients, and the ongoing ability to buy back undervalued shares.

Worth Noting: This strategy typically requires significant insider ownership, as small companies with low management ownership tend to waste considerable time and resources on investor relations, consulting, and other unnecessary expenses.

The strategy that ties them all together – FitLife (FTLF)

No letter I write is complete without mentioning Dayton Judd and FitLife – and for good reason.

Since taking over as CEO in 2018, Dayton has been deliberate in executing multiple of the strategies listed above at various stages of his long-term plan to maximize shareholder value, growing the market cap from ~$5m to now ~$150m.

He began by slashing 60% of costs – including public company costs – and running FitLife like a private company with all his time allocated towards fixing and growing the business (buying back ~5% of highly undervalued shares too).

This was largely made possible because he had majority ownership of the company, and any long-term shareholder who engaged with Dayton recognized him as exceptionally trustworthy and a best-in-class CEO.

He then grew the company out of underfollowed territory by acquiring multiple complementary nutrition brands purchased at distressed multiples of 3–5x earnings and cutting their bloated costs alongside layering in synergies at each step.

Dayton and his team will continue to run this playbook in the future as more acquisitions come their way.

Their long-term plan that maximizes shareholder value – laid out in 2018 – is now methodically coming to life.

He has assembled a conglomerate of complementary brands large enough for a strategic acquirer to pay 12–15x earnings or more – that will only get larger and more valuable as his acquisition playbook continues.

All the while, public costs have remained at $600K per year or below – even after uplisting to the NASDAQ – and the business generates 15–20%+ returns on capital as we wait.

Since 2018, Dayton has given us a clear and concise example of how a long-term plan that maximizes shareholder value is brought to life.

If you don't know where you are going, you'll end up someplace else. — Yogi Berra

The next chapter of 'rolling up my sleeves' is this: thoroughly understanding each company's long-term shareholder value creation strategy prior to acquiring ownership.

For a tiny portion of the companies we currently own that don't seem to have a long-term strategy in place, I have a clear plan to fly out and make a simple pitch on the necessity to have one.

However, all in all, the companies we own have been wonderful stewards of our capital.

In total, a company that passively awaits market recognition – rather than proactively creating its own strategy for the highest possible return for investors – is failing to reckon with an undeniable reality. Price discovery in small, underfollowed public markets may not improve.

The companies that will reward patient shareholders are the ones that stop waiting to be found and start building something that will eventually be impossible to ignore.

The rigorous in person due diligence and the active pitch for buying back shares will of course still be at the core of River Oaks Capital's investment strategy. We have now just added a third dimension.

This represents a significant opportunity for River Oaks Capital, as we have identified a clear pathway to generating above-average returns through small, underfollowed public companies, regardless of the broader market efficiency.

River Oaks Capital puts in the necessary 'time requirement' to find the few undiscovered gems in a forest left for dead.

Part of that 'time requirement' over this past year included traveling to:

Omaha, NELucky, OHRaleigh, NCSt. Louis, MODetroit, MIChicago, ILCharlotte, NCLas Vegas, NVNew York City (4x)Atlanta, GABoston, MASchaumburg, ILCouncil Bluffs, IACharlotte, NCBaltimore, MDIndianapolis, INGreenwich, CTDayton, OH

Cincinnati, OH

Somerset, NJ

Columbus, OH

Durham, NC

Austin, TX

New Orleans, LA Conference

Quick Recap

As outlined in the River Oaks Capital ' Fund Overview ', our ultimate goal is to have our fund invested in 10-15 small, underfollowed wonderful businesses that check all these six bullet points:

  • Sells a wonderful product that will generate substantial cash for years to come
  • Treats their customers, employees, and community admirably
  • Is run by honest and able people who also have ownership in the business
  • Does not take excessive risk
  • Has a long-term plan for the business
  • Is selling ownership at a significant discount to fair value

The oversimplified formula = A+ capital allocator in a wonderful, small, niche business with a valuation that provides a margin of safety.

However, small, underfollowed wonderful businesses are not always selling at a significant discount to fair value, so along the way we will also buy 'excessive discount' companies which are so deeply undervalued – $0.50 or less on the dollar – that almost none of the first five bullet points are needed as virtually any long-term outcome coupled with proper capital allocation will generate an acceptable return.

II. Companies added in the Past Year

Ascent Industries (ACNT)

Ascent Industries is specialty chemical manufacturer. It is the seventh largest position in our fund and has a $150m market cap.

Founded in 1945, Ascent Industries began as a special chemical manufacturing business but spent decades diversifying into stainless steel, fiberglass tanks, and pipe & tubing.

Years of mismanagement under an operationally inexperienced team left the stock flat for nearly two decades, burdened by rising debt, declining earnings, and bloated corporate costs.

This also resulted in no strategic direction for each operating business and no ability to gain economies of scale with each additional acquisition – this became quite evident as capital allocation was getting materially worse each step of the way.

That changed in 2020, when activists Ben Rosensweig (Privet Fund) and Chris Hutter ('UPG') replaced management. Chris stepped in as an unpaid CEO and Ben as Chairman of the Board (where he remains today).

They cut corporate waste, stabilized operations, and sold the Specialty Pipe & Tube business for $55M, leaving the company debt-free.

Chris effectively began establishing the company's long-term strategic foundation; however, persistent profitability challenges led the team to recognize the need for a CEO with industry-specific operational expertise.

Brian and his team step in

In 2023, Brian Kitchen was brought in to lead the specialty chemicals division, becoming CEO of the entire company by 2024.

I flew to meet Brian in Chicago and have gotten to know him quite well over the past year.

I can attest that he is the A+ caliber CEO we are looking to invest alongside, who is building a wonderful, niche business.

Immediately, Brian and the Ascent team decided to divest all of their tubular assets (sales attached here and here) and return to their roots of being a pure play specialty chemical manufacturer with no debt and ~$60m of cash on the balance sheet.

Brian's first order of business, as he told me when I visited him in Chicago, was to "get the band back together."

Brian reunited with CFO Ryan Kavalauskas and the same team that previously turned around ClearOn – a failing water treatment chemical manufacturer losing $8M of EBITDA annually – growing it to $36M of EBITDA in four and a half years before selling it to Solenis in 2022 .

Although there many differences between Ascent Industries and ClearOn, when Brian became CEO of Ascent in 2024, he saw a lot more positives at Ascent than at ClearOn.

First and foremost, Ascent Industries' three manufacturing sites in Tennessee, South Carolina, and Virginia are well-maintained and require minimal capital expenditure ($1–$3m annually across all three), unlike ClearOn, where chemical corrosion continuously degraded equipment which drove significantly higher capital expenditures.

While Ascent's manufacturing facilities are of high quality, their utilization rate across all sites remains below 50% – well short of the 80%+ benchmark expected of a well-run chemical manufacturer with their strategy.

Brian and his team saw this as both good and bad.

The bad news is they had barely enough business to cover the fixed costs of the manufacturing facilities.

Conversely, Brian and his team had the capacity to grow the business significantly without having to invest additional capital expenditure on a new manufacturing facility.

The Turnaround Begins

As mentioned, Brian previously worked with nearly all of the management team he hired at Ascent.

The mutual trust between them has been instrumental in accelerating the execution of the turnaround.

Together they immediately began identifying areas that needed to change for the business to be profitable again.

To begin with, many of Ascent's specialty chemical products were being sold at a loss simply because prices hadn't kept pace with rising input costs. After fixing pricing and exiting unprofitable lines, gross margins have improved from 5% in 2023 to ~30% by Q3 2025 on flat revenue.

The team also shifted the business mix.

When Brian and his team took over, 90% of the specialty chemical business consisted of toll manufacturing ('custom manufacturing') – a lower-margin model in which a company provides its facilities and services to process pre-made chemicals on a client's behalf.

The other 10% of the revenue was 'product sales,' a stickier, more predictable, higher-margin revenue stream where Ascent handles formulation, blending, packaging, logistics, and regulatory compliance of specialty chemicals for their customers – creating a one-stop shop.

Brian and his team's focus on growing 'product sales' revenue is already reflected in the financials, with the revenue mix now trending toward ~65% 'custom manufacturing' and ~35% 'product sales.'

As excess capacity across their three facilities is utilized, 'product sales' should constitute over 50% of revenue.

Brian and his team remain committed to 'custom manufacturing', as a portion continues to yield strong, high-volume returns; however, their primary focus is on "quality margin business," which predominantly falls within the 'product sales' category.

Another issue identified was that, prior to Brian's team's involvement, the business lacked visibility into the markets and applications in which their customers were using its specialty chemical products for.

They uncovered that Ascent was producing an excessive number of specialty chemical products across hundreds of markets.

So, Brian and his team simplified their specialty chemicals end market customers: Oil & Gas, CASE (Coatings, Adhesives, Sealants, Elastomers), HI&I (Household, Industrial & Institutional cleaning applications), and Water Treatment – retiring a sprawling, unfocused product catalog.

After two years as CEO, Brian and his team have homed in on the long-term business plan: being a provider of customized specialty chemical solutions for any small- to mid-size customer with a unique specialty chemical need.

In total, Brian and his team are transforming the business into what he calls a 'Chemicals-as-a-Service' model – further carving out their niche as a one-stop solution for small and mid-size businesses neglected by the larger players.

Ascent Industries solves these customers' problems across the value chain by offering any part of a full suite of services: formulation development, reaction capabilities, blending, packaging, logistics, regulatory support and reliable delivery.

For instance, a small paint company approaches Ascent facing challenges in developing a defoamer for their new paint product.

Brian and his team manage the entire process – from formula development and raw material procurement to blending, regulatory compliance, and final packaging – delivering a product ready for immediate integration into the client's new paint.

No other company offers this level of service.

Future Capital Allocation

The ~$60m cash balance is being deployed by Brian and his team across three priorities:

1. High-return, low risk growth investments within the existing asset base (equipment, salespeople, etc.).

2. Share buybacks – they recently authorized buying back ~20% of their shares over the next two years, on top of the 7%+ already repurchased in the first three quarters of 2025.

3. Disciplined acquisitions of profitable, well run specialty chemical businesses with $0–25m of EBITDA with unique, proprietary chemical products that help fill the remaining capacity at their manufacturing facilities – they are not looking for a turnaround project.

Note: #2 & #3 are of equal priority

The Growth Opportunity & Valuation

Ascent's three well-maintained manufacturing facilities in Tennessee, South Carolina, and Virginia currently operate below 50% utilization, with minimal capex requirements of $1-3m annually across all sites.

This means significant revenue growth requires no additional facility investment.

Brian and his team's near-term plan is to grow revenue from ~$80m to $130m+, representing ~80% capacity utilization.

With the fixed-cost base largely covered, incremental revenue flows heavily to the bottom line. At ~80% utilization, with gross margins expanding to 35%+ (as the revenue shifts toward higher margin 'product sales') and SG&A at ~15% of sales, EBITDA margins should reach 18–20%, or $23–26m+ of EBITDA per year – generating $17–20m+ of free cash flow to equity, a 14–17+% free cash flow to equity yield (6-7 P/E) in the near term at the current market cap (adjusting for cash*).

This near-term target appears increasingly achievable following the company's recent announcements of $10m in new annual recurring revenue and the lease of its previously idle Munhall, Pennsylvania site, generating $2.1m in annual cost savings .

Additionally, we are investing alongside Brian and his team, who possess a proven turnaround track record and a long-term value creation strategy – as mentioned in the opening section – that positions the company to become an undeniably attractive acquisition target.

As shown in this presentation , public costs are itemized to highlight immediately strippable expenses for a strategic acquirer, excluding synergies.

All in all, at current ~50% capacity utilization, Ascent offers an attractive ~9-10% free cash flow to equity yield (10-11 P/E ratio) with meaningful upside potential as the business scales, while its ~$60m of cash on the balance sheet provides capital allocation optionality and downside protection.

While an acquisition is not necessary for us to generate above-average returns, Ascent Industries – once operating near full capacity – would be conservatively worth 70%+ more than its current market cap to a large specialty chemicals manufacturer.

BuildDirect (BILD:CA) (BDCTF)

BuildDirect is a physical and online professional flooring company with locations throughout the U.S and one in Canada. It is the third largest position in our fund and has a $90m market cap. (number are expressed in USD)

For a comprehensive overview of the business, please refer to the H1 2025 letter.

CEO Shawn Wilson continues executing on his plan to consolidate the professional flooring industry through acquiring/building 75+ professional flooring centers.

Over the past six months, I have come to know Shawn even better.

What I continue to admire most about Shawn is his intense discipline towards prudent capital allocation – despite a long-term plan to significantly grow the business – he's methodically growing BuildDirect to generate superior returns for us long-term investors, not just for the sake of growing.

Recent Acquisition

BuildDirect recently acquired Greyn Custom Wood , an established online flooring marketplace with a strong presence in major retailers' (Home Depot, Lowe's, Menards, etc.) e-commerce channels alongside a professional center in South Carolina, for $450k – approximately 1.25x EBITDA on $6m in revenue and ~$320k in EBITDA.

The acquisition is strategically compelling for us investors for three reasons.

First, it provides immediate access to big-box retailers' online marketplaces – a footprint that would have been costly and time-consuming to build organically.

Second, BuildDirect can significantly reduce Greyne's fulfillment costs by routing orders through BuildDirect's now 10 professional centers, replacing the third-party warehousing Greyne previously relied upon.

Third, there are multiple opportunities to cross-sell.

Shawn and his team can leverage Greyne's existing retailer relationships to introduce BuildDirect's products, while integrating Greyne's catalog into BuildDirect's physical and e-commerce channels – creating a clear path to revenue growth.

Based on the above, using conservative estimates, BuildDirect could add $3m+ in incremental revenue and $400k in annual cost savings to Greyne, allowing the acquisition to generate $800k–$1m in free cash flow to equity per year.

Acquiring versus Building

Over the past two quarters, a slower acquisition pace has enabled Shawn's team to assess the merits of acquiring versus building professional centers.

The conclusion is clear: the preferred method for growing from 10 to 75+ professional centers is via acquisitions.

The Orlando center, acquired for ~$600k* at 1–1.5x EBITDA on $5–6m in revenue, is on track to achieve 15–20% revenue growth and EBITDA margins of 12–15% in its first year – a strong outcome driven by ERP integration, procurement savings, and targeted marketing toward professional flooring customers.

Exterior view of a BuildDirect Wholesale Flooring professional center, featuring a red metal frame and a white building with the company logo.

By contrast, the Los Angeles greenfield professional center, built for ~$500K*, is projected to take up to five years to reach $5m in revenue – the level Orlando achieved on day one.

The Los Angeles center has, however, meaningfully reduced west-coast fulfillment costs for the e-commerce business.

Going forward, management will focus on acquiring established, single-digit EBITDA margin 'fixer upper' mom-and-pop professional flooring centers and improving them to 12–15% margins without additional capital investment.

Shawn and his team have been able to structure their acquisitions at or below the value of inventory plus net working capital – providing us investors significant downside protection.

With approximately 15,000 independent professional flooring centers in the market, the pipeline of opportunity remains substantial.

Management is confident it can add 7–10 professional centers per year, though Shawn and his team will only do so on terms that represent sound capital allocation.

Furthermore, if there is an area of the U.S they want to penetrate but doesn't have a professional flooring center for sale – or for sale at a reasonable valuation – they still have no problem building one on their own and recruiting top-tier local talent.

From a big picture standpoint, the flooring industry has experienced a prolonged downturn, driven by persistently weak housing turnover – the sector's primary health indicator – resulting in below-historical-norm acquisition prices as mom-and-pop professional centers are facing significant financial pressure.

A more conservative assumption would be that during normal times, acquiring a local mom and pop professional center would cost 2–3x EBITDA (before synergies), which would be ~2–3x more expensive than building a greenfield professional center of the same size.

Nonetheless, regardless of economic conditions, the preferred growth method for Shawn and his team is through acquisitions.

BuildDirect.com

Recall that when Shawn took over as CEO, he shrunk their money-losing e-commerce business down from $30m–$40m of revenue per year to $15m.

Under the leadership of Jay Allen, their e-commerce site is now profitable again and should generate ~$18m of revenue this year.

The team plans on slowly growing their e-commerce site – by only re-investing the cash generated by the e-commerce division – to a $25–$35m revenue business with a 15–20% operating margin in the near term.

This is all due to the wonderful overhaul Jay Allen has executed – details of how he did so are mentioned in the previous letter.

Valuation

River Oaks Capital's ownership was acquired through a private offering extended to us by Shawn and his team when BuildDirect had a $35m market cap.

At a $90m market cap, the margin of safety is lower than when we bought ownership; however, my deeper understanding of management's capital allocation discipline and the long-term value creation Shawn and his team are in the midst of executing has strengthened my confidence that downside protection remains adequate while the upside potential is significantly more than I initially realized.

Post the Greyne acquisition, BuildDirect should generate ~$80m in annualized revenue with $7–8m in EBITDA, converting to $4–5m+ in near-term free cash flow to equity.

The company has ~$8m in cash on the balance sheet, and its favorable RBC credit facility (prime + 1–1.5%) enables ~60% debt financing on acquisitions.

With their current access to liquidity, management can acquire an estimated 15 additional professional centers over the next 2–3 years, adding $75m+ in revenue.

Combined with e-commerce growth, this positions BuildDirect as a ~$165m revenue business generating $17–20m in EBITDA and $12–14m in free cash flow to equity in the next 2-3 years – implying a 13–15% free cash flow yield (6-8 P/E ratio) and a pathway to self-funded growth toward their goal of 75 professional centers in 10 years (never having to issue shares again).

While the 2–3 year projection carries a lot of “ifs”, Shawn and his team have established a proven framework that has already delivered strong returns for us investors.

I will continue to check in with Shawn and his team to monitor their progress; however, if they continue executing acquisitions like Orlando and Greyne Custom Wood – both projected to have one-year paybacks (100% return on capital) – a $90m market cap appears to be a reasonable valuation

It has been a pleasure investing alongside Shawn and his team.

III. Updates from H1 2025 Letter

Click on each company name below for update

Note: The updates just focus on the last six months of developments in each company so for further details reference previous River Oaks Capital letters here .

Citizens Bank ('CZBS')

Truxton Trust ('TRUX')

Boston Omaha ('BOC')

America's Car Mart ('CRMT')

Old Market Capital ('OMCC')

BankFirst ('BFCC')

Medical Facilities (DR.TO)

Fitlife ('FTLF')

Innovative Food Holdings (IVFH) ('IVFH')

Greenfirst Forest Products (GFFPF) ('GFP')

All Companies below 3% of our fund

We own three companies that are below 3% of the fund: HAYPP Group ('HAYPP'), R&R REIT (RRR.UN), Runway Capita ('RWAY'), and SR Bancorp ('SRBK') . As usual, if our ownership of these companies grows, I will provide a detailed write-up. If you are interested in learning more about these companies now, please feel free to give me a call or I can e-mail you a write-up.

IV. Mistakes

Over the past six years, my investment approach has increasingly focused on identifying 'wonderful businesses' in the small, underfollowed public company universe rather than 'excessive discounts'.

Many of these wonderful businesses possess the capacity for significant, value-accretive growth.

However, a mistake I have made is buying ownership too quickly when a CEO presents a compelling growth plan.

This error has two parts to it:

1. I have purchased ownership based on a convincing growth narrative before any real progress was reflected in the financials.

2. I have done so at valuations that have already priced in a meaningful portion of the growth story.

This brings to mind a principle I have applied since founding River Oaks Capital – Warren Buffett's "Rule No. 1: Never lose money. Rule No. 2: Never forget Rule No. 1."

In these instances, I've failed to fully consider downside protection – specifically, not considering the valuation implications if the growth story never materializes.

There is nothing inherently wrong with investing in a 'wonderful business' on the cusp of material growth, provided it is value accretive.

The discipline, however, lies in buying only when two conditions are met:

1. The growth story is beginning to appear in the financials yet remains largely unrecognized by the market.

2. The valuation is low enough on current earnings that the investment is sound regardless of whether growth materializes.

These opportunities are rare, but rigorous in-person due diligence — particularly in small, underfollowed public markets — can uncover them.

Whether pursuing ‘wonderful businesses’ or ‘excessive discounts’, my approach has always been rooted in value investing, and my mistakes have often occurred when I have drifted from that discipline.

Best,

Whit Huguley, CFA

References

  1. TR = Total Return (dividends reinvested)
  2. Overly conservative assumption that $30m of cash will be needed to help fill capacity
  3. Recall from the previous letter: whether building or buying, they are leasing the 20,000 to 30,000 square foot warehouse, so that isn't factored into the upfront costs (which is a risk I will monitor).

Contact Us

River Oaks CapitalWhit Huguley, CFAPortfolio Manager

River Oaks Capitalwhuguley@riveroaks-capital.com(504) 913-3388
